content.description: Sit start, start holds underlined in yellow. Move up along the left hand side and top out along the spine.
content.location: At the very bottom of the This Is BS boulder.

climbs.name: Tree line
climbs.fa: Has this been climbed before? I dont have a guidebook. Please inform if you know!

content.description: Left hand on a crimped sloper behind the arete or lower on a sloping arete. This option is almost impossible in wet or warm conditions. Right hand starts on the obvious sloper on the right. Then swing for tall "jug" that can either be matched or if you have good hands swing for the even higher and better jug for left hand. Then top out on slopers and a crimp up top. Crux is figuring out the feet on the start. They are low and blind and you need to stack them on a crimp a little ways out to the left under the arete.  Its also irritating that the tree is there but its not in the way except if you fall back on it. Tree is off.
content.protection: This one is fine without a mat/spotter.
content.location:
On the low side of split rock. The left of the two bodies of rock.  In between the VERY obvious tree and to the right of where the uphill  "dislocator traverse" starts when facing the problem. See pictures- 

 Make sure to remove any condoms before climbing.

content.description: Climb the white strip of rock, on the south face of Split Rock. A bit tougher than it looks - Not a good climb for when the rock is wet.
content.location: Easily identified on the south face of Split Rock.

content.description: Contrary to the name, I actually quite love this problem - I'd rate it as one of my favorite V1s in the park. Sit-start on the far-right side of the western-half (non-traverse side) of Split Rock. Traverse left until you reach the somewhat overhung arete, and then top out direct.
content.protection: A pad or spotter might be wanted for the top out, but really isn't necessary. The rest of the route stays very close to the ground.
content.location: All the way on the right of the western half of Split Rock.

content.description: Standing start with hands and feet on the north face of the west-half of Split Rock (if you're on the more elevated side, this is the half on climber's right). Traverse around the corner, over the smaller rock on the ground (careful not to dab, it's off!), and across the entire western face, from left to right, using the lower "rail" of rock. Top out at the end.
content.protection: No pad or spotter really needed, though a pad might be helpful while working the moves - The beta I eventually found required me to move into several positions in which a fall would have meant potentially smashing my head on a rock.
content.location: The entire western face of Split Rock - you know it when you see it!

content.description:
A one-move wonder, though surprisingly tough. Sit-start on the obvious undercling, in the seam left of "This is BS". Crank up to a sloper, and orient carefully to reach out to the line of good edges to the top, with an easy top-out. 

  This route tends to be very friction-sensitive - in the summer, when the rock is greasy, it might require some chalking and drying before it goes.
Start with your left hand on the bulge and right hand on the crack. Move up to the triangular edge, then shift over to the right and top out.
content.protection: A pad is helpful, but not necessary
content.location: Bottom, south side of Split Rock that faces the Loeb Boathouse.

content.description:
This is a R -> L traverse that shares the same middle section with Split Rock Traverse but starts and ends with different holds. 

  Begin at the right end of the traverse face with (crossed) hands on juggy side pulls. Move out to the hairline crimps on the sloper rail and then move up to the higher rail. Traverse the rail and make a big move up and left to the lip just left of the mini dihedral. From here, heel-toe cam the rail as you continue to slap out left along the lip until you can get your feet beneath you on the large holds high up. Work your body over the lip, finishing with a couple delicate slab moves before finishing on the left edge (the really good incut seams on top are off until you reach the left edge)
content.protection: A couple pads or pad + spotter to shuffle it along

content.description:
Nice and shady spot amongst the Rambles, where a climber can be alone, with compelling need for neither spotter nor crashpad. Split Rock only has five established problems on it (ranging from V0 to V5), but some of them are very high-quality, and worth projecting and coming back to. 

  The rock is only steps from Freestanding Rock, down the road from Arch Rock, and (if you're a braver climber than I) Hepatitis Boulder. These three or four together make for a solid little bouldering area.
